Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 48917-001 
Capacity Development Technical Assistance (CDTA) 
December 2014 
 
 
 
Republic of Azerbaijan: Capacity Building for Rural 
Financial Inclusion   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This is the abbreviated version of the document that excludes commercially sensitive and 
confidential business information that is subject to exceptions to disclosure set forth in ADB’s 
Public Communications Policy 2011. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

I.  INTRODUCTION   
1.  The nonsovereign capacity development technical assistance (TA) will be an integral 
part  of  a  proposed  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  investment  to  support  AccessBank 
Azerbaijan (ABA) and Finca Azerbaijan (FIA). The selection of these two financial institutions for 
the TA will encourage improved provision of rural finance through bank and nonbank financial 
institutions using alternative approaches, including mobile banking, new financial and advisory 
products, comprehensive banking services, and enhancement of deposit mobilization in local 
currency.  
 
2.  ABA was established in 2002 and is Azerbaijan’s sixth largest bank. It has a strong 
regional footprint, with 66% of its loan volume and 78% of its loans outside the capital area. 
ABA employs 2,277 staff in 43 branches, of which 28 branches are in the regions.  
 
3.  FIA was established in 1998 serving 153,000 clients covering small and medium-sized 
enterprises (SMEs) (2%) and microenterprises (98%), 55% of which are farmers. FIA has a very 
strong rural footprint, representing over 80% of its loan volume. FIA employs over 1,200 staff in 
65 branches, of which over 55 are in the regions.  
 
II.  ISSUES  
4.  Azerbaijan’s  anticipated  exhaustion  of  oil  and  gas  resources  by  2050  calls  for 
diversification of the economy. A special focus is needed on improving agricultural productivity, 
which generated only 5.3% of gross domestic product (GDP) in 2013. Most of Azerbaijan’s 
9.2 million  residents  live  in  rural  districts  (47%)  and  regional  towns  (31%).  Although  rural 
economic activity contributes less than 10% to GDP, it supports 78% of the population and 38% 
of employment. Many rural Azerbaijanis are engaged in low-productivity agriculture, trapped in 
lowly  paid  jobs,  and  have  not  benefited  from  poverty  reduction  at  similar  rates  as  urban 
residents.1 The growth of economic activity is of particular significance in rural areas, as it 
provides major benefits for low-income families and stimulates demand for goods and services 
produced by farmers and MSMEs. Azerbaijan’s agricultural productivity is hampered by low 
quality standards, small land plots, inadequate infrastructure, lack of knowledge and skills, and 
low access to finance. Food and livestock production, storage, processing, and trading to meet 
domestic  and  export  demand  provide  potential  for  productivity  growth  as  well  as  poverty 
reduction.  
 
5.  With  the  collapse  of the  Soviet  Union,  the  agriculture  sector’s  contribution  to GDP 
contracted from 20% (2001) to 5% (2013). Since independence, 1.3 million hectares of farmland 
have  been  distributed  to  850,000  rural  households.  Small  private  farmers  owning  up  to 
3 hectares now produce more than 90% of the agricultural output; the government continues to 
own most of the pastureland, and cattle farmers may obtain grazing rights from municipalities. 
Agricultural output is equally divided between livestock, cereals, and horticulture (2013). Since 
2000, urbanization increased while the rural population remained almost stable. While cereal 
production substantially improved at a CAGR of nearly 8% during 2000–2009, it has remained 
stagnant since.  
 
6.  Agriculture  has  significant  potential  for  growth  in  Azerbaijan  given  its  climatic  and 
geographic advantages, such as having 9 different climate zones (out of 12 in the world) and 
spring arriving 1 month before the Russian Federation. This diverse seasonality is particularly 
                                                
1 H. Onder. 2013. Azerbaijan: Inclusive Growth in a Resource-Rich Economy. Washington, DC: World Bank.

2   
an advantage for southern and eastern regions, with Azerbaijan’s presence in the food markets 
of the Russian Federation (unprocessed fruits, vegetables, nuts, edible oils, fats, cotton, tea, 
and sugar) and Georgia (sugar, animal feed, and wheat flour). Opportunities to improve value 
addition  include  enhancing  the  processing  of  such  products  in  Azerbaijan.  However,  the 
development of new products and markets will require investment to improve both productivity 
and quality by applying modern technology and international standards.  
 
7.  After  the collapse  of the  Soviet  Union,  macroeconomic  shocks  and financial  crises 
undermined public confidence in Azerbaijan’s banking system. As a result, the penetration of 
financial intermediation remains low. Bank penetration in regions remains low, as many villages 
do not have access to basic financial services. Azerbaijan’s regions, which account for 78% of 
the population and 62% of total entrepreneurs,2 receive only 16% of bank lending.3 Supporting 
the outreach of financial services to the regions will have major qualitative impacts on the 
economy and people by stimulating rural income and employment, in addition to supporting 
diversification.  
 
8.  Banks hold about 95% of finance sector assets, and nonbank financial institutions hold 
the remaining 5%. The banking sector is dominated by the state-owned International Bank of 
Azerbaijan, which holds about 35% of banking system assets.4 However, banking assets are 
well diversified, with the second largest bank holding 5% of bank assets, the 15 largest second-
tier banks holding 45% of system assets, and the remaining 28 third-tier banks holding the 
balance. Total capital adequacy of the banking system  was 18% in 2013, well above the 
regulatory minimum of 12%. Banks reported acceptable past due loans at 5.1% of total loans in 
2013.5 Bank loans have increased at a CAGR of 22% over 2007–2013, with private banks 
(26%)  outpacing  the  International  Bank  of  Azerbaijan’s  growth  (16%).  The  finance  sector 
remains significantly dependent on external commercial borrowing. Loan–deposit ratios remain 
high at 160% (2013), reflecting low public confidence in the banking system, and pointing to 
continued demand for external inflows. Obtaining long-term funds remains a challenge for banks. 
The economy remains highly dollarized, with banks issuing about 30% of loans in foreign 
currency. 
   
9.  The Azerbaijan Microfinance Association has 33 members, including nonbank financial 
institutions  and  banks.  The  association  reported  $1.4  billion  microloans  (or  2%  of  GDP) 
outstanding at 31 August 2014, representing more than 600,000 borrowers and an average loan 
size of $2,320. Women borrowers comprise 26%. From 2008 to August 2014, micro loans grew 
strongly at a CAGR of 19.3%. The association reports overall very good portfolio quality of its 
members—their average nonperforming loan ratio has never exceeded 3.3%.  
 
10.  Access to financial services remains low, with branch penetration of only 9.6 branches 
per 1,000 people (2012). Because of its widely spread population and terrain, the provision of 
banking services is costly in remote areas. Bank lending in rural areas is also limited by the 
riskiness of agricultural loans, lack of financial information on borrowers, and limited availability 
of real collateral in rural areas.  
 
11.  Bank deposit mobilization is weak in Azerbaijan. A survey conducted by Gallup in 2011 
indicates that  only  15%  of the  adult  population  interviewed  had  an  account  with  a formal 
                                                
2  World Bank Group. 2014. Azerbaijan Partnership Program Snapshot. Washington, DC. 
3  Government of Azerbaijan, Central Bank of the Republic of Azerbaijan. 2014. Monthly Bulletin. September. Baku. 
4  The International Bank of Azerbaijan is one of two majority state-owned banks in Azerbaijan. 
5  The reported overdue loans and nonperforming loans are to be treated with caution, as individual banks may follow 
different standards in classifying and provisioning for their loan books.

3 
financial institution, and only 2% of those who saved during the preceding year had done so 
through formal financial institutions.6 This highlights the population’s mistrust in the banking 
system and the limited ability of financial institutions to provide quality deposit services. 
      
III.  THE CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The impacts will be (i) the expansion of private banking services in Azerbaijan’s regions, 
with a special focus on agriculture and rural regions; and (ii) the expansion of private banking 
deposit services.  
 
13.   The first outcome will be that ABA increases local currency deposit mobilization from 
retail customers. Outputs for ABA are (i) a new deposit mobilization strategy and business plan 
are  developed,  (ii)  staff  customer  service  skills  are  improved,  (iii)  mobile  and  self-service 
banking service channels are developed and rolled out, and (iv) a new deposit service concept 
is tested and retail local currency deposits increased.  
 
14.   The second outcome will be that FIA demonstrates the sustainability of lending to SMEs 
and farmers in Azerbaijan’s regions and increases its service reach to more remote regions. 
Outputs for FIA are that (i) an improved MSME lending process is designed and tested, (ii) SME 
loans with a special focus on agriculture are well accepted, and (iii) commercially viable mobile 
service approaches to remote regions are designed and tested.  
  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities   
15.  ABA’s  management  recognizes  the  large  underserved  potential  of  rural  dwellers, 
especially farm households and agriculture-related SMEs. A lack of awareness of rural dwellers 
of  market  opportunities  and  skills  to  plan  and  manage  a growing  business  are  significant 
challenges. As a result, ABA is preparing a strategy to improve the financial literacy of its clients 
and to build their awareness of the benefits of saving. ABA is developing a strategy to provide 
comprehensive  services  and  to  enhance  deposits.  The  strategy  to  provide  comprehensive 
services  includes  (i)  financial  literacy  training  and  business  planning,  (ii)  human  resource 
management and skills development, (iii) marketing, and (iv) innovative services and product 
offering. The strategy will dovetail with the design and testing of innovative financial services 
products to meet customer needs and increase customer loyalty.  
 
16.  The deposit enhancement strategy will entail (i) the design, testing, and rollout of new 
deposit products, including marketing through cross-selling to its borrowers and products based 
on branchless banking; and (ii) establishing test branches where staff are trained to focus on 
customer services. ABA plans to develop a wider deposit base with longer tenors, encourage a 
culture of savings, and promote de-dollarization by focusing on local currency deposits. 
 
 
18.  In response to market demand, FIA raised the upper lending limit from $50,000 to 
$100,000—expecting the SME segment to grow from 1.7% (2014) to 10.0% by 2017. FIA puts 
particular focus on agricultural SMEs. FIA’s SME clients are often existing clients that have 
graduated  from  microenterprise  status—requiring  larger  financing  and  more  sophisticated 
                                                
6  A.  Demirguc-Kunt  and  L.  Klapper.  2012.  Measuring  Financial  Inclusion:  The  Global  Findex  Database. 
Washington, DC: World Bank. page 35.

4   
products. To address underserved remote villages that are difficult to serve through branch 
presence, FIA intends to improve service outreach through mobile delivery channels. These 
may  include  branchless  services  through  electronic  banking  and  physical  delivery  through 
mobile staff and/or agents.  
 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
20.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,150,000, of which $750,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). ABA and FIA will 
fund significant parts of the TA, which is estimated to be no less than 35% of the total TA cost.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
21.  ADB  is  the  executing  agency  for  the  TA,  and  ABA  and  FIA  are  its  beneficiaries. 
Consultants  will  be  engaged  either  as  individuals  or  through  qualified  firms.  ADB  will 
competitively select the consultants for the TA and supervise their outputs in close coordination 
with ABA and FIA, in each case in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2013, as amended from time to time). ADB-funded contracts will be disbursed by ADB in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time) and supervised by ADB. Outline terms of reference for the consultants are in 
Appendix 3. The TA implementation is expected to begin in May 2015 and be completed by 
31 December 2017.   
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding $750,000 on a grant basis for Capacity Building 
for Rural Financial Inclusion in Azerbaijan, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
